desired_output: 8 ounces vegan cream cheese (I love Trader Joe's brand)
1/2 cup lightly packed sun-dried tomatoes (dry, not in oil // chopped // plus more for topping)
1/4 cup lightly packed frozen spinach (thawed and squeezed dry* // optional)
2 large cloves garlic, minced (2 cloves yield ~2 Tbsp or 12 g)
1/4 cup vegan parmesan cheese (plus more for serving)
1 pinch each sea salt and black pepper
2 large flour tortillas (ensure vegan friendliness on package)
½ cup citrus juice (See Notes: I love the mixture of 6 Tbsp lemon juice + 2 Tbsp orange juice)
2 Tbsp mirin (2 Tbsp sake or water + 2 tsp sugar)
½ cup katsuobushi (dried bonito flakes) (packed; 6 g)
1 piece kombu (dried kelp) (2" x 3" strip; 6 g)
1 cup raw cashews (see notes for alternatives)
1/4-1/2 cup granulated sugar or pure maple syrup
1 ounce whiskey or rum, per serving, optional
2 and 1/4 teaspoons Platinum Yeast by Red Star (1 standard packet)*
1/2 cup (120ml) whole milk, at room temperature (between 68–72°F, 20-22°C)
2 and 1/2 cups (315g) all-purpose flour (spoon & leveled), plus more for generously flouring hands, surface, and dough
2/3 cup filling (see recipe notes for options & cheese filling)
4 and 1/4 cups (515g) all-purpose flour (spoon & leveled), plus more for hands and surface
1 and 3/4 cups (420ml) buttermilk, plus 1 Tablespoon for brushing the dough
optional: 1 Tablespoon whole oats and/or a sprinkle of coarse salt for topping
1/2 cup (1 stick; 115g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature
1/2 cup (100g) packed dark or light brown sugar
1 and 1/2 cups (190g) all-purpose flour (spoon & leveled), plus more for work surface
1/2 cup (115g; 1 stick) cold unsalted butter, cubed*
egg wash: 1 large egg beaten with 1 Tablespoon (15ml) milk
optional: sliced almonds and coarse sugar
2 Tablespoons (30g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature
1/2 cup (50g) almond flour or almond meal
3 heaping cups peach slices (about 2–3 medium peaches)*
1 Tablespoon almond flour, almond meal, or all-purpose flour
1 cup (230g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature
1 cup (200g) packed light or dark brown sugar
two 4-ounce semi-sweet chocolate bars, chopped (1 and 1/2 cups)*
optional: coarse sea salt for topping
3/4 cup (170g) unsalted butter, softened to room temperature
your choice of icing (see recipe notes)
2 unbaked Flaky Pie Crust (what I used) or All Butter Pie Crust*
2 and 1/2 cups (about 350-400g) mixed berries or other fruit (see note)
1 teaspoon lemon juice or vanilla extract
optional for topping: coarse sugar and/or chopped/sliced nuts
1 cup (2 sticks; 230g) unsalted butter, cold and cubed
4 cups fresh or frozen cranberries (do not thaw)
1 unbaked Flaky Pie Crust (what I used) or All Butter Pie Crust*
egg wash for pie crust: 1 large egg beaten with 1 Tablespoon milk or heavy cream
2 and 1/2 cups (250g) coarsely chopped pecans (a very rough chop!)
1/2 cup (100g) packed light or dark brown sugar
1/4 cup (60g) unsalted butter, melted and slightly cooled
2 cloves garlic, plus more to taste
1/2 tsp sea salt, plus more to taste
1 cup water or unsweetened almond milk (we did half of each)
10 ounces gluten-free pasta (ensure vegan-friendly as needed // we prefer Trader Joe’s brown rice quinoa fusilli)
1 tsp oil (or sub water, adding more as needed as it evaporates)
1 cup sliced yellow squash or zucchini
1 healthy pinch each sea salt and black pepper
1 tsp dried Italian herbs (oregano and basil // optional)
2 cups spinach (or other delicate green // we found sturdy greens, e.g. kale, to add too much chew)
3 Tbsp peanut butter or cashew butter (to keep this dish truly raw, use raw cashew butter)
1/2 – 1 tsp red pepper flake (adjust to preferred heat level)
5 Tbsp coconut aminos (or tamari, but start with lesser amount as its saltier)
1 Tbsp maple syrup or raw honey, plus more to taste
2 medium carrots, ribboned with a vegetable peeler
1 medium cucumber, very thinly sliced with a vegetable peeler or mandolin
1 cup (packed) red cabbage, very thinly sliced with a knife or mandolin
1 large red bell pepper, very thinly sliced with a knife or mandolin
2 cups chopped curly or lacinato kale
2 Tbsp raw sunflower seeds or sesame seeds
1 batch Marinated Peanut Tempeh or Almond Butter Tofu (optional)
1/2 batch flax egg (1 ½ tsp flaxseed meal + 1 ¼ Tbsp (19 ml) water as original recipe is written)
1/2 cup oat flour (ground from rolled oats // ensure gluten-free for GF eaters)
2 ½ Tbsp organic cane sugar, plus more for topping
2-3 tsp fresh chopped rosemary (organic when possible // optional)
3 Tbsp room temperature coconut oil (scoopable, not liquid or frozen* // or cold vegan butter)
2 large ripe frozen bananas (see slicing / freezing instructions below)
1-2 tsp dandy blend* or espresso powder (or sub a small amount of strong brewed coffee or espresso that’s been chilled — just add slowly as it can make the nice cream watery)
1-2 Tbsp dairy-free milk only as needed (optional)
2 cups cooked chickpeas (preferably home cooked // try our Instant Pot recipe!)
1/4 – 1/2 tsp sea salt (plus more to taste)
1-2 Tbsp extra virgin olive oil (if oil-free, omit)
1 tsp baking soda (helps soften the beans)
~2 – 2 ¼ cups water (just enough water to cover the chickpeas)
1 handful fresh herbs (we prefer thyme or rosemary)
1 healthy pinch each sea salt and black pepper
¼ cup gochujang (Korean chili paste) (4 Tbsp)
½ tsp kosher/sea salt (I use Diamond Crystal; Use half for table salt)
½ lb thinly sliced pork loin (227 g; You can buy thinly sliced meat at Japanese/Korean/Chinese grocery stores or slice the meat yourself following my How to Thinly Slice Meat tutorial.)
4 oz Mizuna (Japanese mustard green) (113 g; or use any green salad)
2 Tbsp soy sauce (I used Kikkoman® Gluten-Free Tamari Soy Sauce)
2 Tbsp sesame oil (I used Kikkoman® Sesame Oil)
¼ tsp freshly ground black pepper
2 ¼ cups dashi (click to learn more about this soup stock) (Homemade ingredients below; or 2 ¼ cup water + 1 to 1 ¼ tsp dashi powder)
1 Tbsp usukuchi (light-color) soy sauce (or regular soy sauce; we use light color soy sauce here so the soup doesn't become too dark)
½ tsp kosher/sea salt (I use Diamond Crystal; Use half for table salt)
1 kombu (dried kelp) (2" x 5", 5 cm x 12 cm)
1 ½ cups katsuobushi (dried bonito flakes) (15 g, 0.5 oz: skip for vegetarian/vegan)
2 servings udon noodles (180 g dry udon noodles; 500 g frozen/boiled udon noodles)
4 Inari Age (seasoned fried tofu pouch) (You can buy canned or refrigerated inariage package; Homemade inariage recipe, click here.)
Shichimi Togarashi (Japanese Seven Spice) (optional; sprinkle at the table)
1 piece aburaage (deep-fried tofu pouch) (¾ oz, 20 g)
6 oz komatsuna (170 g; or any greens such as spinach, bok choy, cabbage, napa cabbage, lettuce, Mizuna, etc)
1 cup dashi (click to learn more about this soup stock) (240 ml)
½ tsp soy sauce (Use gluten-free soy sauce for GF)
½ tsp kosher/sea salt (I use Diamond Crystal; Use half for table salt)
instant ramen noodles (I recommend Sapporo Ichiban brand Shio Ramen - salt flavored)
the leftover Japanese curry of your choice (I used my Japanese Chicken Curry)
1 cabbage (I use ½ green and ½ purple)
other vegetable choices (shelled edamame, bell peppers)
¼ tsp kosher/sea salt (I use Diamond Crystal; Use half for table salt)

¾ lb ground beef & pork combination (12 oz or 340 g; The good beef/pork ratio for hambagu is 2:1 (8 oz/4 oz) or 3:1 (9 oz/3 oz). You can make hambagu with 100% beef; however, it will not be as juicy and tender as combined meat)
½ tsp kosher/sea salt (I use Diamond Crystal; Use half for table salt)
3 Tbsp red wine (for steaming; this mini wine is perfect if you are only using wine for cooking; you can substitute with beef/chicken stock although highly recommend red wine)
3 Tbsp ketchup (Adjust the amount - some ketchup is sweeter than others)

3 Tbsp tonkatsu sauce (Sub: You can use Worcestershire sauce. However, you have to add sugar to balance out the sourness as Tonkatsu sauce is sweeter than Worcestershire sauce. You can also make Homemade Tonkatsu Sauce.)
3 Tbsp red wine (This mini wine is perfect if you are only using wine for cooking; you can substitute with beef/chicken stock although highly recommend red wine)
For Soy Sauce Caramel (yields 1/2 cup or 120 ml)
2 Tbsp soy sauce (I used Kikkoman Gluten-Free Soy Sauce)

½ sheet gelatin (1.1 g; or use ½ tsp gelatin powder; [Equation] 1 envelope gelatin powder (0.25 oz/7 g.) = 1 Tbsp powdered gelatin = 3 sheets GOLD leaf gelatin. One sheet leaf gelatin would correspond to 1 tsp of powdered gelatin.
1.5 lb boneless skinless chicken breasts (680 g; 3 pieces of 8-oz chicken breasts from Costco; you can use chicken thighs or tenders)
½ tsp kosher/sea salt (I use Diamond Crystal; Use half for table salt)
2 large eggs (50 g each w/o shell)
4 cups neutral-flavored oil (vegetable, canola, etc) (960 ml; for deep frying)
Tonkatsu Sauce (or make Homemade Tonkatsu Sauce)
2 large eggs (50 g each w/o shell)
⅓ cup kimchi (60 g; increase more if you like it spicy)
½ tsp kosher/sea salt (I use Diamond Crystal; Use half for table salt) (to taste)
1.8 oz Malony (Glass Noodles) (50 g; You can purchase at Japanese grocery stores and Rakuten)
